awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an Isotope Ratio Mass Spectrometer for Compound-Specific Applications in Biogeochemistry and Environmental Studies at UC Santa Cruz
awd_abstract_narration:
Stable isotope analysis is now one of the most important tools in a remarkable variety of research, with key applications spanning oceanography, biogeochemical cycle research, ecology and food webs, paleoecology, archaeology, and paleoclimatogy. Work in all these areas increasingly requires sensitive analysis of the isotope ratios of a range of elements (carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, sulfur), in a wide variety of sample types, and the most innovative projects increasingly require new, leading-edge approaches, such as isotopic analysis of individual organic compounds (CSIA). This award to the University of California at Santa Cruz (UCSC) involves the acquisition of an isotope-ratio-monitoring mass spectrometer (IRMS) to serve investigators and students across multiple disciplines. This acquisition will have wide broader impacts. First, the instrumentation will significantly expand UCSC's basic research infrastructure, supporting core campus priority areas for excellence in coastal sciences and environmental sustainability research.  It strongly enhances UCSC's core education and teaching mission, allowing graduate and post-doc training on cutting-edge instrumentation while supporting a far greater range of projects.  The instrumentation will support undergraduate research, via senior theses and direct involvement in research labs, as well as the incorporation of hands-on projects into higher level courses. The project team will also develop a new initiative for a summer outreach program, in collaboration with UCSC's division of student success.

UCSC will acquire a Thermo Scientific 253+ isotope ratio mass spectrometer (IRMS), with two front-end peripherals configured for cutting-edge CSIA capabilities, including the ability to make isotopic measurements on unknown compounds, and the addition of sulfur isotope capability. This high-sensitivity IRMS will have two main sample input peripherals: (1) a GC-Trace Ultra-GC coupled to a TSQ Duo Triple Quadrapole Mass Spectrometer, and configured with a programmable Tri-Plus RSH auto-sampler capable of automated derivatization/standard additions; and (2) an IsoLink CNOHS Elemental Analyzer (EA) with a new unified combustion/pyrolysis design that will bring needed sulfur isotope capability. Each component in this configuration was chosen to fulfill a critical need.  The 10 KV 253 IRMS will provide high sensitivity, allowing a range of new, nano-scale compound-specific applications, particularly critical for individual-compound N measurements. The customized Tri-Plus RHS auto-sampler can both make and inject derivatives with automated addition of internal standards. This will provide high sample throughput. The TSQ Duo Triple Quadrapole Mass Spectrometer represents a completely novel, cutting-edge capability, allowing researchers to simultaneously identify unknown structures as they measure their C and N isotope ratios.  Finally, the EA IsoLink (CNSOH) interface will bring the ability to measure S isotopes to UCSC for the first time, allowing 13C, 15N, and 34S values to be measured simultaneously on a single sample, even at extremely high C/S ratios (e.g., wood samples).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

The University of California, Santa Cruz (UCSC) has a long history of influential research and education in the environmental sciences, with researchers and students in departments across three academic divisions, and serving as a central degree granting institution and partner for education, training and research in both government agencies and NGO's located across central California. To support this work, novel isotopic methods have become increasingly critical to unraveling interactions among changing climate, biogeochemical cycles, and ecosystems past and present, on land and sea. Specifically, the analysis of stable isotope ratios of environmentally important elements (carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, sulfur) in a variety of substrates now underpins a huge range of environmental and climate change research. Such analyses refer to the measurement of the relative ratios of light to heavy forms of common elements, for example the ratio of 12C to 13C, in a sample. These ratios can then serve as a tracer for a wide variety of environmental and/or biological processes.

Increasingly the leading edge of this work has focused on analysis of not just isotope ratios in total samples, but measurement of these ratios in individual organic molecules, or even specific parts within molecules. These measurements are made with highly specialized instruments called isotope ratio mass spectrometers, designed to first convert elements to pure gases, and then to measure the isotope ratios of specific elements at extremely high precision. A foundation for future advanced research, as well as training students at the forefront of modern technology, is therefore having access to these highly specialized instruments.

The Light Stable Isotope Laboratory (SIL) is the largest shared analytical facility at UCSC. Our campus' long-term success in interdisciplinary and groundbreaking environmental and climate research has in large part rested on having cutting edge instrumentation housed here, and operated within an open-access, shared facility which supports hands-on student and postdoctoral training, as well as regional and national visitors. However, since the last upgrade in the early 1990's, advances in instrumentation and technology have far outstripped the lab's instrument capabilities. The principle aim of this MRI proposal was to rectify this situation, with new stable isotope instrumentation representing a major upgrade to the shared UCSC-SIL facility, and a return to the forefront of modern technology and capabilities.

This proposal supported the acquisition, installation, and commissioning of one of the most advanced isotope measurement systems in the world: a thermo scientific Delta + isotope ratio mass spectrometer, coupled to two "front end" systems for introducing specific sample types: first a bulk elemental analyzer, capable of measuring isotopes of H, O, S, C, and N in total (or "bulk") samples, and second a directly integrated state-of-the-art ultra-high resolution Orbitrap Mass Spectrometer. The first of these  two upgrades and replaces an existing aged unit, while also bringing for the first time the ability to do sulfur isotopes to UCSC. This new capability is particularly important in both archaeological and origin of life research, and will greatly expand the kinds of projects the facility can accommodate. The second capability (high resolution mass spectrometry, coupled directly with isotope ratios) is almost unique in the world, and the first configuration of its kind in the United States. It allows the measurement of highly precise isotope ratios on unknown molecules, with the simultaneous generation of precise atomic formulas and ability to solve unknown structures. This configuration enormously expands possible stable isotope analyses, and exact molecular identities not longer need to be determined before work begins. 

Finally, an additional important project goal was to expand training and direct research experience of underrepresented STEM groups, opening doors to real laboratory participation using this advanced instrumentation. To do this, the project broader impacts component developed a new outreach workshop specifically for UCSC's most at risk community college transfer students. Integrated into a residential weeklong summer program for incoming transfer classes, this new workshop serves to introduce students directly to professors and researchers associated with the UCSC-SIL lab, and then match interested students directly with research opportunities.

Overall, the new MRI instrumentation  will have major and long-term impacts across multiple areas. The isotope ratio / orbitrap instrumentation is at the very leading edge of isotope geochemical instrumentation, coupling the power of stable isotopes with ultra-low level organic molecule measurements and structural information, and opening wide new applications in areas ranging from reconstructing past ocean ecosystems and earth climate, to modern ecosystem connections, novel pollution research, and even ancient metabolisms in geobiology. Most broadly, the expanded instrument capacity in this widely used facility will enable more cutting-edge work, while opening up significant new opportunities for education and training of more diverse graduate students, postdocs, and undergraduates.
